Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story:
The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm cut through the clamor of hammers and drills, and I dropped my tools, heart pounding. As a construction laborer, I knew the rules: when the alarm sounds, you don’t hesitate. You leave everything and head straight to the muster point, no questions asked. My foreman’s eyes met mine, urging me to move, to be part of the team, to keep everyone safe.

But today was different. Today was the main weekly service at the chapel, the one I lead as the community’s priest. The pews would be filling with people seeking comfort, guidance, and the prayers I promised to deliver. They counted on me to be there, to offer them hope and connection. My phone buzzed in my pocket—messages from parishioners asking if I was on my way.

I stood frozen, torn between the blaring alarm and the silent pull of my congregation. The weight of both uniforms pressed on me, the hard hat and the collar, each demanding my presence, each with its own urgency. My hands trembled as I tried to decide which duty I would betray.
